item.title: Post 2
item.description:
hello

E-mail

Believe or not, e-mail can still be used communication; it isn‚Äôt just something you need to confirm your account when registering for other services.

  • aetherway@disroot.org

XMPP

I‚Äôve wanted to use XMPP ever since I first learned about it a few years ago‚Äîa still-active relic from the 2000s, before social media and smartphones took over. Back then, this was how we communicated online: a small pop-up window on your computer displaying your contacts and their status‚Äîonline, offline, busy, or away. That whole concept feels somewhat obsolete now, given our constant presence on the web. But I don‚Äôt think signaling our availability is pointless. Sometimes, we just want to chat.

item.title: Share your art struggles. I'll start.
item.description:
March 5, 2025

I pour my struggles into my characters, but unless I spell it out, no one seems to notice. Maybe I need to approach this differently. So I‚Äôll try again.

I‚Äôve been doing commissions for years now‚Äîit‚Äôs how I make a living. But lately, even picking up a pencil feels impossible. Drawing used to be what I loved most. Now I write stories just to avoid it.

I‚Äôm grateful to those who have supported me, truly. I don‚Äôt expect anyone to fix this, but I just need to say it: I feel drained. Completely. I don‚Äôt think I can deliver my best anymore.

item.title: Subscribe to RSS!
item.description:
February 22, 2025

The push to revive the ‚Äòold web‚Äô‚Äîwith platforms like NeoCities‚Äîbrings back the late ‚Äô90s and early 2000s aesthetic. But pairing it with RSS feels anachronistic, as they come from different eras. A niche pre-Twitter technology, RSS never saw mainstream adoption.

Still, RSS offers a way to follow sites like social media‚Äîwithout algorithms. In an internet dominated by curated feeds and walled gardens, it remains a direct, decentralized alternative.
